content: jessica s jellyfish a crochet amigurumi pattern 2007© j robinson you can do what you like with whatever you make using this pattern but the pattern itself is not to be sold by anyone other than me thanks materials needed yarn◊ red heart baby medium weight color #1975 seashore hook◊ size g/6-4 25mm stitch marker a small piece of yarn works well stuffing scissors or something with which to cut the yarn gauge my gauge is 5 stitches x 4 5 row per square inch but the gauge is not very important for this project if your gauge is smaller or larger than mine that will only affect the size of the finished product by creating a smaller or larger jellyfish what is important is the size of hook and weight of yarn in order to get the nice tight stitches that give crocheted amigurumi its signature look use a hook that is one size smaller than what the yarn label recommends however if you normally crochet tightly using the recommended hook size will be fine ◊ any yarn and hook is okay to use for this project as long as it fits in with the above paragraph glossary decrease - decrease single_crochet two together increase - increase work two single_crochet in the same spot single_crochet - single_crochet sl - slip_stitch chain - chain stitch - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - magic_ring wrap yarn around yarn-holding hand hand a as if ready to crochet leave a tail about six inches long pinch the tail with this hand so the tail dangles pick up the end of the dangling yarn with the other hand hand b make a u shape with the yarn between the two hands close the top of the u by putting the tail end of the yarn behind the working yarn so the two strands cross with the thumb and forefinger of hand a pinch and hold where the strands cross each other now there should be a ring shape held in the pinching fingers of hand a the tail end should be behind the working yarn and dangling toward the floor pick up the hook with the free hand and hold it as if to crochet from behind the ring insert pinky finger of the hook-holding hand into the ring and put gauge on the ring by pulling slightly against the other hand s hold on the ring into the front of the ring insert the hook grab the working yarn pull it through the ring towards you chain 1 i learned of this technique online from crochetme com where there is an illustrated tutorial http //www crochetme com/node/105/print notes as you will notice when you start the pattern i leave out the traditional connecting stitches between rounds because i think that gives the rounds a cleaner seamless look but without those connecting stitches it is impossible to see where the round starts and stops so that
